captions.text:
Hades 2 is, my powers of deduction inform me, the 
sequel to Hades 1, an isometric hack-and-slash

game by Supergiant Games with lots of very sexy 
voiced dialogue, and represents on multiple levels

a very significant development in the path of 
this particular... developer. For one thing,

it means we now have to refer to Hades 1 as 
Hades 1 like it&#39;s some kind of particularly

ill-fated space mission. And secondly, this is 
the first time Supergiant Games have ever made a

sequel when all of their games up to now have been 
unique, original IPs. Fuckin&#39; boooo, Supergiant,

you used to be one of the good ones. What happened 
to the sheer unbridled creativity that gave us

Bastion, an isometric hack-and-slash game with 
lots of sexy voiced dialogue, or Transistor,

an isometric hack-and-slash game with lots of—you 
know what? Actually, forget I said anything. &quot;Hey,

you forgot to mention Pyre, Yahtzee, that 
wasn&#39;t a hack-and-slash game.&quot; Oh hey,

what&#39;s that on the floor? It&#39;s the riff you just 
killed, asshole. Remind me not to ask you to pet

sit. Hades 2, then. I was looking forward to 
this &#39;cause obviously, I really like Hades.

Roguelikes are a bit old hat, yeah, 
and games based on Greek mythology are,

if anything, even older hat; that&#39;s some 
fucking stovepipe shit, but what set Hades

apart was its phenomenally good writing. 
I loved its subversive twist on the old

Orpheus plot where instead of descending into the 
underworld to reach the lair of the final boss,

you basically start out in the lair of the final 
boss and have to make your way up to the nice,

quiet meadow on the surface that would 
conventionally be the starting area,

where the final boss shows up incredibly annoyed 
at the cost of the Uber he had to take to get

there. And I liked how Hades wasn&#39;t a stock 
evil revenge-seeking bad guy type but a sort

of gruff but caring grumpy dad and the conflict 
stemmed more from an inability to communicate and

a tendency to send loads of dudes to hit us with 
swords a whole bunch. So, I was keen to know what

Hades 2 was gonna bring to the table. &quot;Glad you 
asked, Yahtzee! We&#39;re gonna subvert things even

further! Now, instead of ascending out of the 
underworld to the surface, you have to descend

from the surface to the underworld and beat the 
final boss in his lair! And this time, the final

boss IS a stock evil revenge-seeking bad guy who 
isn&#39;t complex at all, woo! Double subversion!&quot;

Wouldn&#39;t that just be a &quot;version?&quot; Oh, and the 
main character has a vagina instead of a penis

now, which is more of an INversion, thinking 
about it. Melinoë is the second child of Hades

and younger sister of Zagreus who was sent as a 
baby to live in the woods with Hecate before the

Underworld got conquered by the Titan Cronos, 
mysteriously resurrected and with a real nark

on for the Olympian gods, presumably because of 
all that unfortunate castration business in the

original myth. Raised by Hecate as a warrior, 
Melinoë must now fight her way down to the

former house of Hades, confront the Titan of Time, 
and shove a grandfather clock up his arse. Now,

I do like Hades with its beautiful hand-painted 
character art and seemingly bottomless well of

dialogue variants that means even 300 runs in, the 
cast are still finding new and interesting ways

to talk about whatever obscure figure from Greek 
mythology handed you your own ovaries recently,

but while all of that was still in evidence, 
I felt initially disappointed that Hades 2

seemed to be mainly going over the same beats 
as the first game. Hang out in home base,

select a weapon, crawl the same four dungeons. 
With little changed besides which specific

figures from Greek mythology we hang out with 
now. Oh, Odysseus is here instead of Achilles,

wow. What a fucking sea change. Trading in 
heel anecdotes for whining about dead dogs.

The format of the room-by-room dungeon clearing is 
the same, although the third area is based around

exploring large open spaces &#39;cause I guess that&#39;s 
about the time the level designers knock off for

lunch. And combat&#39;s still based around a variety 
of unlockable weapons with a normal attack,

a special, and a cast, although there is slightly 
more of an emphasis on holding buttons down to

do magic-infused attacks, which I&#39;m not huge 
on; holding down buttons versus tapping them

in hectic, fast-paced combat is like putting on 
Wellington boots for the 100-meter sprint. Nyehh,

non-committal noises; come on, what else&#39;re 
you doing that&#39;s new, Hades 2? That isn&#39;t just

new wallpaper on the old format. &quot;Er... you can 
grind up resources with which to craft upgrades

now!&quot; For the sake of our friendship, I&#39;m going to 
overlook the implication that I should get excited

about that. &quot;Well, I guess you&#39;re right, Yahtz. 
It&#39;s more of the same. Sorry for disappointing

you; I&#39;ll just leave now out through this door.&quot; 
What door, Hades 2? &quot;Oh, just this door over here

that leads up from the hub area and doesn&#39;t 
unlock until like six hours in.&quot; And where

does that door lead, Hades 2? &quot;Oh, nowhere much, 
just an entire fucking second Hades game bolted

onto the side of this one. With new levels and 
bosses and characters and story and everything.&quot;

Oh my god, the levels even have unique environment 
design. What a fucking flex. What a tease. See,

as well as dealing with Cronos himself, Melinoë 
has to ascend Mount Olympus to rout Cronos&#39; forces

there after she&#39;s crafted a special potion 
that means she can survive on the surface

for prolonged periods. Hang on a minute, wasn&#39;t 
the fact Zagreus couldn&#39;t survive outside the

Underworld the whole thing driving the plot 
of Hades 1? If only he&#39;d known he was one

bowl of minestrone away from resolution the 
whole time. What this means is when you get

bored of taking the Cronos path, you can have 
a few whacks at the Olympus path for variety,

and it all ensures that Hades 2 is a game 
I officially never get bored of. That said,

the Olympus route is quite a bit harder, so 
towards the end after I&#39;d beaten the Cronos

route enough times that there was nothing more 
to gain or learn and I was basically swatting

Cronos back and forth across his boss arena with 
a tennis racket every time, I was stuck beating

my head against Mount Olympus over and over again 
while the game very patiently waited for me to be

less of a crapout so it could finally show me 
this exciting conclusion it had put together.

And incidentally, in the words of everyone who 
used to like Ridley Scott, FUCK Prometheus. But

in contrast to Silksong, I never resent the 
difficult bits &#39;cause I can always wind down

from my defeats with some character moments and 
optional challenges and maybe lez up with Nemesis

in the bath. Hades 2: The Real Slim Shades is an 
example of what I tend to think of as a We Love

Katamari sequel. Which is to say, a sequel that&#39;s 
really just the first game but more polished and

more of it. And I&#39;m not gonna talk it down for 
that much because phwoar crikey is there more

of it. It&#39;s gonna make it fucking hard to go back 
to the first one, for which my only real complaint

was that the gameplay eventually got samey, and 
I never had that feeling from Hades 2. Even in

my non-work hours, I&#39;ve been playing its olives 
off and see no reason not to keep doing so. Yeah,

guess it&#39;s a strong recommend. You know, 
I talk shit about games constantly going

back to Greek and Norse mythology, but in this 
age of video on demand, it&#39;s gratifying that

there&#39;s still some kind of monoculture in the 
world. It&#39;s nice to see familiar faces. Oh hey,

Prometheus. You&#39;ve gained weight since God 
of War 2. Please stop kicking me in the face.
